moves.1. g3 Nf6 2. Bg2 e5: Agaianst Kasparov's Hungarian Opening, Sting makes common-sense moves to seize the center.
moves.3. d3 Bc5 4. Nf3 d6 5. O-O O-O: So far so good for the musician. Both men still have to develop their Q-side pieces before the middle-game proper can begin.
moves.6. c4: With Sting's position oriented towards seizing K-side space, the champion counters with a Q-side thrust.
moves.6... Nc6 7. Nc3 Bg4: No fear. If anything, Sting has the advantage in space.
moves.8. h3 Bxf3 9. Bxf3 Qd7: Sting's development is complete. He has a slight advantage in space and time.
moves.14. Qc2 Re7 15. b4 Ba7 16. Nc3 Rfe8: Kasparov has caught up in development and neutralized the musician's former advantage in space. The position is roughly even.
moves.17. Bd2 d5: The first error from Sting. This move loses a Pawn without significant compensation.
moves.18. cxd5 Nd8 19. e4 h6 20. Be3 b6: Down in material, Sting wisely refuses the exchange of Bishops.
moves.21. Ne2 Nb7 22. g4 Rc8 23. Ng3: Kasparov maneuvers his Knight to the K-side. N-B5 is now a positional threat, as it would force ...P-N3, weakening the Black K-position.
moves.24. Qc6 Qxc6 25. dxc6: With the Queens gone, the position assumes an endgame-like character. Kasparov's extra Pawn is a larger advantage with every exchange of pieces.
moves.25... Rd8 26. a4 Nc8 27. Rfd1 Re6 28. b5: Locking the Q-side Pawns in place, but completely trapping his KB. This piece is now useless.
moves.29. Bf3 Red6 30. Be2 Nh7 31. h4 Ne7: Sting is defending with pluck. However, Kasparov's extra Pawn and Sting's imprisoned B are huge handicaps.
Sting brings his available forces to the K-side.
moves.36. h5 Ng5 37. Kf1 Nh3 38. Bg4 Nf4 39. d: Kasparov's pressure finally forces a mistake.
moves.43. Bd1 Rde8 44. f3 Rd8 45. Bb3: The musician, effectively down 2 pieces, finally resigns. A hard-fought game.

players: Garry Kasparov  vs. Gordon M. T. Sumner
